elements.title: Waharoa (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Waharoa (pictured), a sculpture by artist Selwyn Muru, was created to metaphorically turn Aotea Square in Auckland into the courtyard of a Māori meeting house?

elements.title: Betty Lou Raskin (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that chemist Betty Lou Raskin said in 1958 that society was wasting the "brainpower" of women, and blamed the media for making the mink coat the "symbol of female success" and not the lab coat?

elements.title: The Drunkard's Progress (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that The Drunkard's Progress suggests that a single social drink leads to poverty, crime, and suicide?

elements.title: James Light (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that James Light was threatened by the Ku Klux Klan when he staged a play with an interracial couple?

elements.title: Calypso Cabaret (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the performers in the Thai drag show Calypso Cabaret impressed Lady Gaga with their ability to be open about their identities?

elements.title: William Winstanley Hull (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that William Winstanley Hull's search for the original manuscript of the 1662 prayer book led to its later discovery?

elements.title: Clark Lake Park (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that it cost the city of Kent, Washington, $7.2 million to complete a trail around Clark Lake Park?

elements.title: Sukhbir Singh Gill (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Indian field hockey player Sukhbir Singh Gill continued to play professionally after being diagnosed with a brain tumor in 2006?
